questions.question: The cumulative distribution function of a random variable x is the probability that X takes the value?

answers.a: less than or equal to x

explanations.a: Let $X$ be a real random variable. The function $F_X$ defined over $R$ through $F_X(x)  :=P_X((-\infty, x]) =P(X \leq x)$
explanations.b: Let $X$ be a real random variable. The function $F_X$ defined over $R$ through $F_X(x)  :=P_X((-\infty, x]) =P(X \leq x)$
explanations.c: Let $X$ be a real random variable. The function $F_X$ defined over $R$ through $F_X(x)  :=P_X((-\infty, x]) =P(X \leq x)$
explanations.d: Let $X$ be a real random variable. The function $F_X$ defined over $R$ through $F_X(x)  :=P_X((-\infty, x]) =P(X \leq x)$

questions.question: Consider two identically distributed zero-mean random variable U and V. Let the cumulative distribution function of U and 2V be F(x) and G(x) respectively. Then, for all values of x.?

explanations.a: F(x) is CDF of U than  F(x)= p(U≤ x) G(x) is CDF of 2V than G(x)= p(2V≤ x) G(x)=p(V≤ x/2) given U and V are identical therefore F(x)=p(V≤ x) and G(x)=p(V≤ x/2) F(x) - G(x)= p(V≤ x) - p(V≤ x/2) go by option  let x=2 than F(2)-G(2)= p(V≤ 2) - p(V≤1) p(V≤ x) $ightarrow$ probability from -infinity to x therefore  p(V≤ 2) - p(V≤1)≥ 0 ⇒F(x)-G(x)≥ 0
explanations.c: for x=-2 F(-2)-G(-2)= p(V≤- 2) - p(V≤-1) p(V≤- 2) ≤  p(V≤-1) $ightarrow$ F(x)-G(x)≤ 0 for x≤ 0

questions.question: Consider a random variable X that takes values +1 and −1 with probability 0.5 each. The values of the cumulative distribution function F(x) at x = −1 and +1 are?

explanations.a: Given that P(-1) =0.5 and P(1) =0.5. So, at all other points, p must be zero as the sum of all probabilities must be 1. F(X) is the cumulative distribution function and let P is the probability and given X is random variable, So F(X) = P[X ≤ x] F(-1)=P(X <= -1 = P(x = -1) =0.5 and F(1)=P(X <= 1) =P(x = -1) + P(x = 1) =0.5 + 0.5 =1
explanations.b: Given that P(-1) =0.5 and P(1) =0.5. So, at all other points, p must be zero as the sum of all probabilities must be 1. F(X) is the cumulative distribution function and let P is the probability and given X is random variable, So F(X) = P[X ≤ x] F(-1)=P(X <= -1 = P(x = -1) =0.5 and F(1)=P(X <= 1) =P(x = -1) + P(x = 1) =0.5 + 0.5 =1
explanations.c: Given that P(-1) =0.5 and P(1) =0.5. So, at all other points, p must be zero as the sum of all probabilities must be 1. F(X) is the cumulative distribution function and let P is the probability and given X is random variable, So F(X) = P[X ≤ x] F(-1)=P(X <= -1 = P(x = -1) =0.5 and F(1)=P(X <= 1) =P(x = -1) + P(x = 1) =0.5 + 0.5 =1
explanations.d: Given that P(-1) =0.5 and P(1) =0.5. So, at all other points, p must be zero as the sum of all probabilities must be 1. F(X) is the cumulative distribution function and let P is the probability and given X is random variable, So F(X) = P[X ≤ x] F(-1)=P(X <= -1 = P(x = -1) =0.5 and F(1)=P(X <= 1) =P(x = -1) + P(x = 1) =0.5 + 0.5 =1
